title: Research on sustainable paving/surfacing for low volume rural roads in Vietnam

author: Robert Petts, global Transport Knowledge Partnership

The work was carried out by.
A Corporation of insect associates TRL and an organization called OTB.

One of those meters of rain may come in a couple of days.
Labor wage rates are about $1 a day.
So you probably all feel overpaid.
We're talking about very challenging terrain, from mountains to deltas that flood, so for periods of the year, our roads can actually disappear underwater, not just a couple of centimeters.
A couple of meters of water.

Some have motorized vehicles as we know them.

Other countries in the region, but other developing countries in general.

An unsustainable reliance on gravel roads there.

Is rarely achieved and we shall see later if you can't.

Please don't construct it.

The dry season problem.
We have losses of dust which gets gets into everybody's property into their clothes into their vehicles.
Into their computers onto their crops, whatever, and in the wet season we have losses due to rainfall, so it is quite a substantial problem in these high rainfall and seasonal rainfall climate.
So the paper basically presents the research in Vietnam.
This is only one of the research programs that have been going on.
There has also been complementary search in Lao and Cambodia.
So in the presentation, I first want to talk about the linkage between poverty and poor Rd access.
Then go on to talk about the limitations of the traditional gravel use and then introduce the surface options which will give us reduce maintenance and are more sustainable.

We're not inventing new technology, which is rediscovering knowledge that we collectively have lossed or have just put on the shelf and neglected.

Is linked to poor access.

Long correlation between the poverty rate and lack of access.

The other development agencies are.
Are trying to support the host countries and developing in rural economic and social development.

It's not just Rd projects, health projects, education projects, commercial activities are all constrained.

They can see the the benefits of good, permanent or year access.

We usually been using gravel roads.
They're very attractive, very low initial cost.
They're very easy, relatively easy to construct, although many contracts will give you specifications on grading, plasticity, etc.

Because they knew that a certain type of gravel.

Problems of location of gravel in the Mekong Delta.

Degree.

Deposits not not like a Hard Rock deposit so.
These are serious environmental and sustainability issues.
A range of constraints means that maintenance is rarely carried out.

I still have not found a developing country that has managed to come to grips with achieving good sustainable maintenance.

So there are two parts to the two major parts to the research in Vietnam.
First of all was a survey of over 700 roads that were constructed.
In the previous five year.
And.
We surveyed the, amongst other things, the loss of gravel material from the surface.
And this is the overall chart.
We assess that from local conditions, a loss of up to 20 millimeters a year could be sustainable if maintenance was arranged.
But anyway, a loss of more than 20 millimeters a year would not be sustainable, so you can see here that.
About 60% of the roads were deemed to be unsustainable.
From from the research we came up with a set of guides.
And where you should not use gravel, so we're trying to restrict the application of gravel here.
So the first recommendation was that where graphic quality is poor.
And quite a substantial amount of gravel that had been put down did not meet any recognizable national or international specification.
So at least there should be some some quality assurance on the durability of the the aggregate, the grading and plasticity.

It's a common problem in developing countries.

As I said, the by their nature these natural gravel deposits are very limited and what you find is happening is as you come into the maintenance cycle you're having to go even further and further to to bring your gravel to redo, to carry out the periodic maintenance.

And there is of course an issue that hauling gravel repeatedly over other roads is causing damage to those roads as well, and that this this issue is often not taken account of in in project assessment.
Whole distances along that I mentioned Mekong Delta in Vietnam hauling up to 200 kilometers, we would suggest a whole life costing if you have to hold more than 10 kilometers.
We would say if rainfall is more than two meters a year, I don't think many places in Europe suffer from this, but certainly in in the tropics more than two meters a year, or if you have very high.
Just lost in the dry season.
And of course this means that if you're constructing a Rd through a village or a built up area, you should also consider the consequences of using gravel.
Traditionally, we've always said traffic levels of more than 200 motor vehicles.
They are not appropriate for gravel.
I think we would still stick with that.
But on the other hand.
Old rule of thumb was that if if.
You had traffic between 50 and 200 vehicles a day.
Gravel would be appropriate.
I would say that you need to look at all of these other issues and basically ignore that.
That rule of thumb because in certain circumstances you should never never build a gravel Rd.
But I would say that 200 motor vehicles today.
Upper limit is still valid.
We've always been.
I advise that we should not put gravel on gradients of more than six.
6% this is documented in whole TRL overseas Rd note literature.
So from the experience in Vietnam we would say if you have more than a meter of year meter of rain a year, you should restrict that to 4%.
Don't put gravel on weeks, upgrades, or if it's going to flood.
You will end up with the results that you saw in that photograph.
Compaction of thickness.
These are contractual issues that are often ignored with the use of gravel.
Uh.
Adequate compaction, watering to get the.
The ideal density and characteristics.
And thickness control.
Very often we find contractors say they put 20 centimeters down, but if you go back a few months later, it's pretty obvious they put a lot less than that down.
And of course.
Gravel is a pretty corruptible surface.
It of all the road surface is.

It is the one that contractors can actually cheat the most on, because you can go back six months, nine months later, and then you ask the contractor where the material is and he said, oh, we, had we had a storm last week, and most of it went.
I'm afraid so.
With all the other paving types you can go back and test what was delivered.
I don't use gravel.
If you can't provide camberton side drainage that these are basic engineering fundamentals, but again too often ignored by our practitioners in the field.
Now this is the last point, but I think it in Rd assessment in project planning on whether you should use gravel and indeed with that for any surface you should actually start with.
What is the maintenance regime?
Because it's patently obvious that in most developing countries you don't have a working maintenance regime, so that should influence your design process.
For example, you could say that if if you don't have a working maintenance regime on at least 50% of the road network, don't.
Don't put in a surface that is going to exacerbate or increase that maintenance liability.
So these were the guidelines that we came up with.

Solution.

Whole life costing.
Politicians, engineers very very much look at the initial cost of anything.

They don't have the time or the resources.

So the research in Vietnam has yielded three key outcomes.
That the use the unbridled or uncontrolled use of gravel is not not very sensible, and that gravel is not sustainable for about 60% of situations in Vietnam.
There are more sustainable technologies instead of gravel.
This has led to substantial change in the approach of the Government of Vietnam.
We were working with a previous World Bank Road project.
The latest project is incorporating all these research findings.
Uh, there's about 100 and $50,000,000 of money going into the latest.
The latest project and I don't think there's much gravel in in that project, whereas the previous projects were nearly all gravel roads.
Asian Development Bank is also coming in and adopting these these new proposals, alternative service things and up their program is about same value.

We thought we had an impact on about 300 million dollars worth of local projects as well as spinoffs into other countries.

Produce appropriate, affordable solutions for a range of.

Program or partnership and that is just started a few months ago.

So the research in Vietnam has yielded three key outcomes.
That the use the unbridled or uncontrolled use of gravel is not not very sensible, and that gravel is not sustainable for about 60% of situations in Vietnam.
There are more sustainable technologies instead of gravel.
This has led to substantial change in the approach of the Government of Vietnam.
